lines.text: Enter ROMEO

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: He jests at scars that never felt a wound. But, soft! what light through yonder window breaks It is the east, and Juliet is the sun. Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon, Who is already sick and pale with grief, That thou her maid art far more fair than she: Be not her maid, since she is envious Her vestal livery is but sick and green And none but fools do wear it cast it off. It is my lady, O, it is my love! O, that she knew she were! She speaks yet she says nothing: what of that Her eye discourses I will answer it. I am too bold, tis not to me she speaks: Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven, Having some business, do entreat her eyes To twinkle in their spheres till they return. What if her eyes were there, they in her head The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars, As daylight doth a lamp her eyes in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night. See, how she leans her cheek upon her hand! O, that I were a glove upon that hand, That I might touch that cheek!
JULIET appears above at a window

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Ay me!

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: She speaks: O, speak again, bright angel! for thou art As glorious to this night, being oer my head As is a winged messenger of heaven Unto the whiteupturned wondering eyes Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him When he bestrides the lazypacing clouds And sails upon the bosom of the air.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo Deny thy father and refuse thy name Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love, And Ill no longer be a Capulet.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: [Aside]  Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Tis but thy name that is my enemy Thou art thyself, though not a Montague. Whats Montague it is nor hand, nor foot, Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part Belonging to a man. O, be some other name! Whats in a name that which we call a rose By any other name would smell as sweet So Romeo would, were he not Romeo calld, Retain that dear perfection which he owes Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name, And for that name which is no part of thee Take all myself.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: I take thee at thy word: Call me but love, and Ill be new baptized Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: What man art thou that thus bescreend in night So stumblest on my counsel

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am: My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself, Because it is an enemy to thee Had I it written, I would tear the word.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words Of that tongues utterance, yet I know the sound: Art thou not Romeo and a Montague

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: With loves light wings did I oerperch these walls For stony limits cannot hold love out, And what love can do that dares love attempt Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: If they do see thee, they will murder thee.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye Than twenty of their swords: look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: I would not for the world they saw thee here.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: I have nights cloak to hide me from their sight And but thou love me, let them find me here: My life were better ended by their hate, Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: By whose direction foundst thou out this place

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: By love, who first did prompt me to inquire He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes. I am no pilot yet, wert thou as far As that vast shore washd with the farthest sea, I would adventure for such merchandise.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Thou knowst the mask of night is on my face, Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny What I have spoke: but farewell compliment! Dost thou love me I know thou wilt say Ay, And I will take thy word: yet if thou swearst, Thou mayst prove false at lovers perjuries Then say, Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo, If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully: Or if thou thinkst I am too quickly won, Ill frown and be perverse an say thee nay, So thou wilt woo but else, not for the world. In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond, And therefore thou mayst think my havior light: But trust me, gentleman, Ill prove more true Than those that have more cunning to be strange. I should have been more strange, I must confess, But that thou overheardst, ere I was ware, My true loves passion: therefore pardon me, And not impute this yielding to light love, Which the dark night hath so discovered.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: Lady, by yonder blessed moon I swear That tips with silver all these fruittree tops

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: O, swear not by the moon, the inconstant moon, That monthly changes in her circled orb, Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: What shall I swear by

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Do not swear at all Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And Ill believe thee.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: If my hearts dear love

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Well, do not swear: although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract tonight: It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be Ere one can say It lightens. Sweet, good night! This bud of love, by summers ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet. Good night, good night! as sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast!

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: What satisfaction canst thou have tonight

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: The exchange of thy loves faithful vow for mine.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it: And yet I would it were to give again.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: Wouldst thou withdraw it for what purpose, love

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: But to be frank, and give it thee again. And yet I wish but for the thing I have: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep the more I give to thee, The more I have, for both are infinite. I hear some noise within dear love, adieu! Anon, good nurse! Sweet Montague, be true. Stay but a little, I will come again.
Nurse calls within
Exit, above

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: O blessed, blessed night! I am afeard. Being in night, all this is but a dream, Too flatteringsweet to be substantial.
Reenter JULIET, above

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed. If that thy bent of love be honourable, Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow, By one that Ill procure to come to thee, Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite And all my fortunes at thy foot Ill lay And follow thee my lord throughout the world.

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: [Within]  Madam!

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: I come, anon.But if thou meanst not well, I do beseech thee

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: [Within]  Madam!

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: By and by, I come: To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief: Tomorrow will I send.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: So thrive my soul

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: A thousand times good night!
Exit, above

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: A thousand times the worse, to want thy light. Love goes toward love, as schoolboys from their books, But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.
Retiring
Reenter JULIET, above

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Hist! Romeo, hist! O, for a falconers voice, To lure this tasselgentle back again! Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of my Romeos name.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: It is my soul that calls upon my name: How silversweet sound lovers tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears!

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Romeo!

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: My dear

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: At what oclock tomorrow Shall I send to thee

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: At the hour of nine.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: I will not fail: tis twenty years till then. I have forgot why I did call thee back.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: Let me stand here till thou remember it.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: I shall forget, to have thee still stand there, Remembering how I love thy company.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: And Ill still stay, to have thee still forget, Forgetting any other home but this.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Tis almost morning I would have thee gone: And yet no further than a wantons bird Who lets it hop a little from her hand, Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, And with a silk thread plucks it back again, So lovingjealous of his liberty.

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: I would I were thy bird.

lines.speaker: juliet
lines.text: Sweet, so would I: Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing. Good night, good night! parting is such sweet sorrow, That I shall say good night till it be morrow.
Exit above

lines.speaker: romeo
lines.text: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast! Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest! Hence will I to my ghostly fathers cell, His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.
Exit
